Welcome.WelcomeTitle: Help transform our understanding of Angiosarcoma.
Welcome.WelcomeText: If you have been diagnosed with angiosarcoma, join a nationwide movement of patients, doctors, and scientists by sharing your tumor samples, your medical information, and your voice.  Together, we can develop a comprehensive resource that will drive discoveries about this orphan cancer.
Welcome.SmallTitle: If you have angiosarcoma, you have the power to accelerate cancer research in a way that no one else can.

FirstBlock.Title: Your tumor and medical records could unlock discoveries.
FirstBlock.Text: The unique genetic information in your cancer could hold the key to rapid advances in cancer treatment. By looking at the DNA in your samples, researchers can make discoveries that will ultimately lead to a better understanding and faster advances in the treatment of angiosarcoma. This information will be invaluable to cancer research for years to come.

SecondBlock.TitlePt1: Become an integral part of the research movement.
SecondBlock.TitlePt2: Have a direct impact on the future.
SecondBlock.Text: By saying "Count Me In" you will partner with leading research institutes, hospitals, and patient advocacy groups by sharing part of your stored tumor tissue and copies of your medical records.

FirstStep.Title: Step 1
FirstStep.Subtitle: Tell us about yourself
FirstStep.TextPt2: and complete a simple online form to tell us about yourself and your cancer. We are asking all patients with angiosarcoma to say "Count Me In" and fill out the form so that we can learn more about your experiences with angiosarcoma.

SecondStep.Title: Step 2
SecondStep.Subtitle: Give us permission to collect your samples and data
SecondStep.Text: After you fill out the online survey, we will ask you to complete an online consent form that requests your permission to obtain copies of your medical records and some of your stored tumor tissue. We will do the rest — we'll contact your doctors and hospitals to obtain copies of your medical records and a portion of your stored tumor samples. We'll also send you a simple kit to collect a saliva sample.

ThirdStep.Title: Step 3
ThirdStep.Subtitle: Learn with us along the way
ThirdStep.Text: We are excited to learn with you! Throughout the project, we will provide you with regular updates about the status of the project and share any discoveries that you have enabled us to make. We also may ask you additional questions about your experience to help with future studies — we want to hear what's important to you.

FourthBlock.Text: We are asking you to say "Count Me In" and donate something invaluable to cancer research. Your tissue samples and medical information will be used for transformative genomic studies that will ultimately lead to a better understanding and faster advances in the treatment of angiosarcoma.

FifthBlock.Title: Our Advocacy Partners
FifthBlock.Quote: Angiosarcoma Awareness Inc. is thrilled the Broad Institute is conducting a program similar to the Metastatic Breast Cancer Project whereby patients are given the opportunity to accelerate the pace of discovery by donating their stored tissue samples and medical records. We hope this and similar initiatives will progress new studies ultimately leading to cures for aggressive and rare diseases.

SixthBlock.Text: With your help, patients can be the driving force behind cancer research.

PageHeader.Pt1: The Angiosarcoma Project is part of
PageHeader.Pt2: a nonprofit organization that brings together patients and researchers as partners to accelerate discoveries in cancer research.

AboutUs.Title: About us

Content.Pt1: is stewarded by four leading organizations: Emerson Collective, a California-based social change organization; the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, a leading nonprofit biomedical research institution; the Biden Cancer Initiative, an independent nonprofit organization that builds on the federal government’s Cancer Moonshot; and the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, a leading cancer hospital. For more information about

AboutUs.Quote: Angiosarcoma Awareness Inc. is thrilled the Broad Institute is conducting a program similar to the Metastatic Breast Cancer Project whereby patients are given the opportunity to accelerate the pace of discovery by donating their stored tissue samples and medical records. We hope this and similar initiatives will progress new studies ultimately leading to cures for aggressive and rare diseases.

DataRelease.Title: ASCproject Data
DataRelease.ViewPaperButton: VIEW OUR PUBLISHED RESEARCH ON THE ASCPROJECT

MainText.Section1: The ASCproject has released data that is publicly available in cBioPortal. This data is being released as it is generated, and as the project continues to enroll patients, more data will be added regularly.
MainText.Section2: We have focused our efforts on generating and releasing this data so that the entire research community can have access to it. As we generate more data over time, we anticipate that this will accelerate discoveries in angiosarcoma.
MainText.Section3: To everybody who is taking part in the ASCproject, we would like to extend our most sincere gratitude for your partnership that enables the generation of this data.

InformationList.Title: Below, you will find the following information:
InformationList.Item2: Additional information about this data release
InformationList.Item3: List of common terms used in this research
InformationList.Item4: Link to the methods used to generate this data

Contact.TextPt1: Please feel free to contact us at
Contact.TextPt2: with any questions and include “Data Release” in your email subject line. This page will be updated regularly with additional information.

BioPortal.Title: The ASCproject Data on cBioPortal
BioPortal.Link: Visit cBioPortal to explore the ASCproject data

DataRelease.AdditionalInfoTitle: Additional Information About the Genomic Data Release

Goal.Title: What is the goal of this data release?
Goal.Text: The goal of this public data release is to share clinical, genomic, molecular, and patient-reported data on angiosarcoma to accelerate discoveries and the development of new treatment strategies in this exceedingly rare cancer. Our goal is to add new data to the collection every 6 months.

Difference.Title: What makes this data different from what is found in existing studies?
Difference.Text: The collection of data in this release is different for several reasons:

ReasonsList.Item1: ALL patients included in the study have angiosarcoma.

Item2.SubItem1: Whole Exome Sequencing (WES) on all samples (as compared to a targeted sequencing panel or other more limited testing)
Item2.SubItem2: Samples annotated with demographic, diagnostic, and pathology data (we plan to add more clinical data to subsequent data releases)
Item2.SubItem3: Samples annotated with patient-reported data from the ASCproject enrollment survey

ReasonsList.Item3: All of this data has been generated through direct partnership with patients

Additional.Title: Will the ASCproject generate and release additional data?
Additional.TextPt1: Yes, the ASCproject is an ongoing research initiative. The project will continue to enroll patients and request saliva, blood, and tissue samples indefinitely. Our goal is to release additional data every 6 months as it is generated. We have already had two data releases in 2018.
Additional.TextPt2: We also will be adding additional clinical fields, captured from patient medical records, as we learn more about what information is most valuable to the research community. In upcoming releases, we plan on adding additional fields including:

FieldsList.Item2: Information on location of metastatic sites

DataIncluded.Title: What data elements are included?
DataIncluded.Text: Data is included for the following categories:

DataList.Item1:
Genomic Information
Whole Exome Sequencing (WES) information for each tumor sample, including mutations, small insertions/deletions, amplifications, and deletions.
DataList.Item2:
Medical Record (MedR): All information that was derived from a medical record is denoted with the prefix MedR
Information about diagnosis that was abstracted from patients’ medical records.
DataList.Item3:
Pathology (PATH): All information regarding pathology is denoted with the prefix PATH
Detailed histologic information about each sample was abstracted by an expert pathologist who reviewed each sample after it was acquired by the ASCproject.
DataList.Item4:
Patient-reported (PRD): All patient-reported data elements are denoted with the prefix PRD
Every patient that registered for the study had the option of completing a 17-question survey about their experiences with angiosarcoma. Thirteen questions from this survey have been abstracted for inclusion. These responses have been cleaned and formatted to prevent individual identification without altering scientific utility.

Resources.Title: Are there resources to define the terminology used in this data release?
Resources.TextPt2: page are The National Cancer Institute’s comprehensive dictionary of clinical terms, as well as definitions of some common genomic terms.

Cite.Title: How should this data be cited?
Cite.TextPt1: We encourage use of this data for your research studies and publications. To help us track data usage, we kindly ask that you send us an email at
Cite.TextPt2: to let us know whenever you have published or presented work using or referencing this dataset. We also request that you please include the following attribution: "The results included here include the use of data from The Angiosarcoma Project (https://ascproject.org/), a project of Count Me In (https://joincountmein.org/)."

Unknown.Title: Why are some attributes “Unknown” for some cases and not for others?
Unknown.Text: All of the clinical information that is gathered comes directly from medical records or pathology reports. If the complete report or record that was received did not explicitly contain the information, the field was marked as “Unknown” in order to ensure accuracy.

Samples.Title: Why are there more samples than patients?
Samples.Text: For some patients, we were able to obtain multiple biopsy samples. Multiple biopsy samples are requested in cases where having multiple biopsies can help answer an important scientific question and where there is ample tissue available for research while still ensuring that tissue is left behind for future clinical use.

Sequence.Title: Will everyone who registers for this study have their tumor sequenced?
Sequence.Text: As of September 2018, over 338 women and men with angiosarcoma have registered for the project and over 125 loved ones have filled out a survey on behalf of a loved one who passed away from the disease. Of these registrants, over 286 have provided consent. Approximately 174 patients have sent in saliva kits. Medical records and tumor samples are being requested for everyone who has signed the consent form that allows for tissue acquisition and who lives in the USA or Canada. Obtaining medical records and tissue samples is a manual process involving faxes, phone calls, and additional follow up. The ultimate goal is to obtain medical records and tumors from as many consenting patients as possible, and to release new data in 6 month intervals as it is generated.

Inform.Title: Can I use this data to inform my clinical care?
Inform.Text: This data is intended to be used for research purposes only. Genomic data included in this study is generated in a research lab, not in a clinical lab. All annotations have been de-identified. Therefore, this data cannot be used to inform clinical decision-making. Some of the data has been intentionally altered to protect confidentiality in a way that does not affect data integrity (for example, Age at Diagnosis has been binned in 5 year intervals).

Item1.Text: Detailed methods for how these data were generated and analyzed.

Item3.Text: Forms documenting informed consent and contact information.

Item5.Text: Included in each blood sample kit.

Glossary.Title: Glossary
Glossary.Text: For reference to common terms used in cancer care and research use the National Cancer Institute Dictionary of Cancer Terms

Additional.TextPt1: If there are additional terms that you would like defined that are not included in the National Cancer Institute Dictionary, please send an email to
Additional.TextPt2: and include “New Glossary Term:” in your email subject line. We will be creating a glossary to define some of the genomics terms seen on cBioPortal.

Disclaimer.Title: View ASCproject Data
Disclaimer.Text: You are now leaving the ASCproject website and will be directed to cBioPortal. Please note that as these data were generated by the ASCproject in a research, not a clinical, laboratory, they are for research purposes only and cannot be used to inform clinical decision-making.

SessionWillExpire.Text: To protect your privacy, the system is going to log you out because you have been away for a while. Click “Continue” to stay logged in. Click “Sign Out” if you are done for now.
SessionWillExpire.RenewalFailed: Session renewal failed. Please log out and log back in again.

Warning.Title: Download Chrome or Safari to Continue
Warning.Text1: This project is designed for use with the internet's safest and most popular browsers -- Chrome and Safari.
Warning.Text2: It looks like you are using Internet Explorer. You will need to use another browser in order to join the project. We suggest you use Chrome or Safari to ensure that your experience with the website is smooth and secure.

Text3.Pt1: Click the following links to download
Text3.Pt3: Chrome and Safari are always free.

MoreDetails.Title: Learn more about the Angiosarcoma Project

Section1.Pt1: The Angiosarcoma Project takes a new approach to cancer research in which researchers partner directly with patients, who share their samples and clinical information in order to speed important discoveries. The project is part of
Section1.Pt2: a nonprofit organization that brings together patients and researchers as partners to accelerate discoveries in cancer research.
Section1.Pt3: is stewarded by four leading organizations: Emerson Collective, a California-based social change organization; the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, a leading nonprofit biomedical research institution; the Biden Cancer Initiative, an independent nonprofit organization that builds on the federal government’s Cancer Moonshot; and the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, a leading cancer hospital.

MainText.Section2: Our goal is to reach out to patients with angiosarcoma around the country in order to study their cancer using cutting-edge genomic and molecular research studies performed at the Broad Institute by allowing patients to participate in these studies regardless of where they live.

AboutYourself.Title: A. Tell us about yourself.
AboutYourself.Text: Click "Count Me In" and complete a simple online form to tell us about yourself and your cancer. Our goal is to perform genomics studies that will enable us to understand the genomic underpinnings of this disease. In order to understand this disease, we need to hear about your experiences with angiosarcoma and couple that information with what we learn from the DNA in your tumor.

Permission.Title: B. Give us permission to collect your samples and data.
Permission.Text: After you fill out the initial survey, we will ask you to fill out an online consent form that requests your permission to obtain copies of your medical records and some of your stored tumor tissue. We’ll also ask you to tell us where you received your medical care so we can contact your doctors and hospitals.

Request.Title: C. We’ll find and request your records and tissue.
Request.Text: Our team will contact your doctors and hospitals to obtain copies of your medical records and a portion of your stored tumor samples. We will ask pathology departments to share only a part of the tumor tissue, and not to share anything with us that might be needed for clinical care.

SendUs.Title: D. Send Us a Saliva Kit.
SendUs.Text: We’ll also send you a simple kit to collect a saliva sample, which will contain "healthy" DNA that can be compared with DNA from your tumor sample.

Analyze.Title: E. We’ll Analyze Your Tumor and Medical Data.
Analyze.Text: We will perform cutting-edge, comprehensive genomic analyses on your tumor and saliva sample. Sequencing data we generate will be securely stored in a protected database at the Broad Institute along with information from your medical record. Any information that would make it easy to identify you as an individual will be removed from all genomic and clinical data.

Share.Title: F. We’ll Share the Data with Other Researchers.
Share.Text: Once potentially identifying information has been removed, our database of genomic and medical information (with your identifying information removed) will be shared with the National Institutes of Health and the cancer research community, and will be able to be used for other genomic and molecular studies to help understand angiosarcoma and develop new therapies.

Learn.Title: G. Learn with us along the way.
Learn.Text: We are excited to learn with you! Throughout the project, we will provide all patients who say "Count Me In" with regular updates about the status of the project and information about new studies that we are conducting. We will also share any discoveries from these research projects with you. We also may ask you additional questions about your experience to help with future studies — we want to hear what’s important to you.

Goal.Question: 1. What is the goal of this project?
Goal.Section1: This project will connect angiosarcoma patients across the country with scientists using cutting-edge technology to study cancer's genetic and molecular causes. Cancer is not a single disease, and each tumor holds part of the puzzle.
Goal.Section2: Because angiosarcoma is so rare, very few patients have the ability to contribute their tumor samples and clinical data to cancer research, largely because they do not have a way of doing so. We believe everyone should have the opportunity to contribute to research, especially now that the combination of genome sequencing and internet-based communication has made it easier to give people that opportunity.
Goal.Section3: We hope our studies will help us understand the genomic landscape of angiosarcoma. By discovering the genes that drive this disease, we hope to be able to design effective therapies to treat angiosarcoma.

Text.Pt1: This project is being conducted by
Text.Pt2: a nonprofit organization that brings together patients & researchers as partners to accelerate discoveries in cancer research.
Text.Pt3: is stewarded by four leading organizations: Emerson Collective, a California-based social change organization; the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, a leading nonprofit biomedical research institution; the Biden Cancer Initiative, an independent nonprofit organization that builds on the federal government’s Cancer Moonshot; and the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, a leading cancer hospital. The ASCproject also works in collaboration with a growing coalition of nonprofit advocacy partners. Our team — led by Dr. Corrie Painter, a cancer researcher and patient advocate— is made up of cancer researchers, physicians, clinical specialists, and patient advocates. Learn more

InvolvedInProject.Question: 3. How have patients been involved in the design of this project?
InvolvedInProject.Section1: This project would not be possible without the influence of patient Lauren Ryan, founder of Angiosarcoma Awareness Inc., and initiator of an online support group for angiosarcoma. Her efforts effectively networked patients from around the world into a robust patient community which is driving this project.
InvolvedInProject.Section2: We have worked closely with patients and patient advocates within the angiosarcoma community from the beginning of this project through its design and implementation. Patients have been involved in all aspects including concept, goals, messaging, forms, and even the design of this website.
InvolvedInProject.Section3: We're proud to have as our Advocacy Partners Angiosarcoma Awareness Inc., The Sarcoma Foundation of America, Target Cancer Foundation, Sarcoma Alliance for Collaboration through Research (SARC), and the Paula Takacs Foundation for Sarcoma Research.

Costs.Question: 4. Are there any costs for me to participate?
Costs.Text: No, there are no costs to you.

TumorTissue.Question: 5. After I provide my information, will I be asked to share my tumor tissue and medical records?
TumorTissue.Text: We will be asking for consent from all patients with angiosarcoma who enroll in this study. As part of the process of providing consent, we will ask your permission to share your stored tumor tissue. We will keep you informed about our progress along the way.

TissueSample.Question: 6. If I am asked to share a tissue sample, will my tissue be used up?
TissueSample.Text: We will take every measure to ensure that your samples are not used up as a result of these studies. We will ask the pathologists who have access to your stored tumor samples to make sure that they share only a small portion with us. If there doesn’t appear to be enough to allow for future clinical testing, we will not request for your samples to be sent to us, and we will notify you that we did not use your samples for this reason.

TissueAndMedicalRecords.Question: 7. If my tissue and medical records are analyzed, will I receive any information back from this study?
TissueAndMedicalRecords.Text: Because our sequencing tests are performed in a research lab and not a clinical lab, we are not currently permitted to return personal genetic data to you. However, we will regularly update you with key discoveries that we make about this disease, overall results, and progress made through this research.

Profit.Question: 8. Is this research being conducted for profit?
Profit.Text: No. This project is a not-for-profit, academic research endeavor. Our mission is to generate data to freely share in a way that protects your personal information with the research community in order to fuel scientific discoveries.

InfoForPhysicians.Question: 9. Is there information that I can bring to my doctor so that I can discuss this study with them?
InfoForPhysicians.Text: Yes, you can print out or use your mobile device to share the document linked here:

Section1.Text: You can access a 1 page printable information sheet about the project linked here:

Section2.TextPt1: If you have any other questions, please email us at

StayInformed.Title: Stay Informed!
StayInformed.Text: Thank you for joining the email list. We'll send you updates and keep you informed. You can unsubscribe at any time. If you have any questions about your status in the project, please email

Password.Title: Please enter the password
Password.OtherError: We're sorry, but an error has occurred.

LovedOneThankYou.Title: Thank you!
LovedOneThankYou.ThankYou: Thank you for taking the time to take the survey and share your thoughts. We will use your feedback to help guide the future design of this project.
LovedOneThankYou.StayInTouch: We’ll stay in touch with you so that you can see the progress that we are making as a result of your participation. In addition to our news blog, we keep you updated by email when we make significant advancements in our understanding of this disease.

Contacts.TextPt1: We'd also like to hear from you if you have any additional thoughts you'd like to share — please feel free to email us at

LovedOneThankYou.ThankYouAgain: Thanks again for helping us and the entire angiosarcoma community! The success of this project is completely dependent on engaged patients who are willing to participate and spread the word. Please help us reach other patients with angiosarcoma to let them know about the project -- with your help, we can launch a movement that will allow all patients with angiosarcoma to drive the discoveries we so desperately need.

InternationalPatients.Title: Information for International Patients

ThankYou.TextPt1: Thank you for your interest in joining the Angiosarcoma Project. Currently, the Angiosarcoma Project is open to patients in the United States or Canada. From the Country field on your survey, it appears that you do not live in the United States or Canada. If you do live or are treated in the United States or Canada, please reach out to us at

InternationalPatients.Understand: We understand that the experiences of every patient matter, and we eventually want to extend these studies internationally. Understanding where people are registering from may enable us to better understand what parts of the world might be most interested in participating in the future of Count Me In projects.
